solution.text:
On simplifying \(\sqrt {_{{j*j}}_}+ \sqrt {_{k}_}\)
we get \(=_{j}_+\sqrt {_{k}_}\)
_{j}_ is an integer and every integer is a rational number
\(\sqrt {_{k}_}\) can not be expressed as integer as we know square root of any prime number is not an integer
\(\sqrt {_{k}_}\) is an irrational number
Now we know that sum or difference of any rational and irrational number is irrational.
hence \(\sqrt {_{{j*j}}_}+ \sqrt {_{k}_}\) is an irrational number
If any number is irrational , by definition it can not be expressed in the form of \(\frac ab\) where \(a\) and \(b\) are comprime

content.text: Can we find a pair of coprime numbers \(a\) and \(b\) (b \(\neq \) 0) such that \(\sqrt {_{{j*j}}_}+ \sqrt {_{k}_}=\frac ab\)
